Award.AwardTitle: EDU: Developing a "Protect", "Use" and "Analyze" Approach to Cybersecurity Competitions in the Healthcare Environment (PUNCCH)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is addressing the question of why there are few women in the growing cybersecurity profession. One of the first exposures to cybersecurity for young people is often a cybersecurity competition, offered at the high school and college levels. Most of these competitions have a "male" focus, based on military "capture the flag" principles. As a result, very few females attend them. The purpose of this project is to develop a female-friendly cybersecurity competition, which is based on three concepts: (1) an alternative view of cybersecurity, using "protect", "use" and "analyze" approaches; (2) systems and data in the healthcare environment where security and privacy are increasingly important; and (3) a competition designed by university students (male and female) for high-school students. The project integrates the development of the competition into existing courses. Marymount University is the location for this project: it has both healthcare and information technology programs in the same school and a diverse student body that is also 70% female. For the first competition, students, and their teachers, are invited to attend a summer camp to cybersecurity principles and practices, with the competition at the end of the camp. University students act as mentors and invited speakers present cybersecurity as a career. Student workers then act as mentors for local area teachers providing them with gender-neutral materials as they prepare other students for a second stand-alone cybersecurity competition. Assessment includes the perceptions of students (male and female) to the cybersecurity field before and after the competitions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project centered around attracting more young females into the male-dominated cybersecurity field (recent studies show that only 10-11% of the cybersecurity workforce are females, in government and industry). Specifically, the project was to engage middle and high school girls in cybersecurity competitions and activities which focused less on “attack” strategies, and more on “protect” strategies such as protecting the privacy of their family’s healthcare records. In addition, they would be exposed to cybersafe in their online behavior, and that of their friends.

Three summer day camps were held (2014, 2015, and 2016) with a specific focus on cybersecurity and healthcare. There was an average of 22 students in each annual camp, and about 25% of them were female. The program was led by a female cybersecurity expert and was taught primarily by female instructors, some of whom were high school teachers. The camp culminated in a half-day cybersecurity competition that involved protecting health care records and investigating data breaches of those records.

The competitions were developed by graduate and undergraduate students at the university, who were specializing in health information technology, under the direction of the cybersecurity faculty. These students, 50% male and 50% female, also supported students in the week-long summer camp, leading lab sessions and providing mentorship.

In addition, the project team worked extensively with local secondary school teachers to develop their ability to teach cybersecurity in their schools such that it was attractive to girls. High school teachers were invited to attend the summer camp and participate in any and all activities. There were on average 3 high school teachers at each year’s summer camp. These teachers left with instructional material, including a variety of hand-on activities which made use of open-source tools, to use at their home institutions. The university faculty also worked with a local high school system to develop a cybersecurity curriculum for its Career Center, again using many of the resources developed for the summer camps. This was piloted in the 2015-16 school year by a high school teacher who participated in the summer camp the year before. It was successful and then fully implemented in the 2016-17 school year.

In 2016, a Cyber Educators Group was formed at the university to continue this goal. Local middle and high school teachers can meet, in person and virtually, to discuss pedagogical strategies in cybersecurity, including making it attractive to females. They have access to all the resources from the summer camps and can share their own content and experiences as cybersecurity is now perceived as an important subject to be integrated into middle and high school curriculum. Several of these teachers, 50% of whom are female, are also taking graduate level cybersecurity courses so that they can participate in dual-enrollment (courses that give both high school and college credit).

As part of its broader impact, the university will continue to expand its body of material suitable for teaching cybersecurity in a female-friendly manner at the middle, high and college levels. This material is freely available to educators. as is participation in the Cyber Educators Group.
